metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: DTD - Elements
In a DTD, elements are declared with an ELEMENT declaration.
content.html: In a DTD, elements are declared with an ELEMENT declaration.

content.text: Declaring Elements
In a DTD, XML elements are declared with the following syntax:
content.html: In a DTD, XML elements are declared with the following syntax:

content.code_html:
<!ELEMENT element-name category>
or
<!ELEMENT element-name (element-content)>

content.text: Empty Elements
Empty elements are declared with the category keyword EMPTY:
content.html: Empty elements are declared with the category keyword EMPTY:

content.code: Example: XML example:
content.code_html:
<!ELEMENT element-name EMPTY>

Example:

<!ELEMENT br EMPTY>

XML example:

<br />

content.text: Elements with Parsed Character Data
Elements with only parsed character data are declared with #PCDATA inside parentheses:
content.html: Elements with only parsed character data are declared with #PCDATA inside parentheses:

content.code_html:
<!ELEMENT element-name (#PCDATA)>

Example:

<!ELEMENT from (#PCDATA)>

content.text: Elements with any Contents
Elements declared with the category keyword ANY, can contain any combination of parsable data:
content.html: Elements declared with the category keyword ANY, can contain any combination of parsable data:

content.code_html:
<!ELEMENT element-name ANY>

Example:

<!ELEMENT note ANY>

content.text: Elements with Children (sequences)
Elements with one or more children are declared with the name of the children elements inside parentheses:
content.html: Elements with one or more children are declared with the name of the children elements inside parentheses:

content.code_html:
<!ELEMENT element-name (child1)>
or
<!ELEMENT element-name (child1,child2,...)>

Example:

<!ELEMENT note (to,from,heading,body)>

content.text: When children are declared in a sequence separated by commas, the children must appear in the same sequence in the document. In a full declaration, the children must also be declared, and the children can also have children. The full declaration of the "note" element is:
content.html: When children are declared in a sequence separated by commas, the children must appear in the same sequence in the document. In a full declaration, the children must also be declared, and the children can also have children. The full declaration of the "note" element is:

content.code_html:
<!ELEMENT note (to,from,heading,body)>
<!ELEMENT to (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT from (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT heading (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT body (#PCDATA)>

content.text: Declaring Only One Occurrence of an Element

content.code_html:
<!ELEMENT element-name (child-name)>

Example:

<!ELEMENT note (message)>

content.text: The example above declares that the child element "message" must occur once, and only once inside the "note" element.
content.html: The example above declares that the child element "message" must occur once, and only once inside the "note" element.

content.text: Declaring Minimum One Occurrence of an Element

content.code_html:
<!ELEMENT element-name (child-name+)>

Example:

<!ELEMENT note (message+)>

content.text: The + sign in the example above declares that the child element "message" must occur one or more times inside the "note" element.
content.html: The + sign in the example above declares that the child element "message" must occur one or more times inside the "note" element.

content.text: Declaring Zero or More Occurrences of an Element

content.code_html:
<!ELEMENT element-name (child-name*)>

Example:

<!ELEMENT note (message*)>

content.text: The * sign in the example above declares that the child element "message" can occur zero or more times inside the "note" element.
content.html: The * sign in the example above declares that the child element "message" can occur zero or more times inside the "note" element.

content.text: Declaring Zero or One Occurrences of an Element

content.code_html:
<!ELEMENT element-name (child-name?)>

Example:

<!ELEMENT note (message?)>

content.text: The ? sign in the example above declares that the child element "message" can occur zero or one time inside the "note" element.
content.html: The ? sign in the example above declares that the child element "message" can occur zero or one time inside the "note" element.

content.text: Declaring either/or Content

content.code_html: <!ELEMENT note (to,from,header,(message|body))>

content.text: The example above declares that the "note" element must contain a "to" element, a "from" element, a "header" element, and either a "message" or a "body" element.
content.html: The example above declares that the "note" element must contain a "to" element, a "from" element, a "header" element, and either a "message" or a "body" element.

content.text: Declaring Mixed Content

content.code_html: <!ELEMENT note (#PCDATA|to|from|header|message)*>

content.text: The example above declares that the "note" element can contain zero or more occurrences of parsed character data, "to", "from", "header", or "message" elements.
content.html: The example above declares that the "note" element can contain zero or more occurrences of parsed character data, "to", "from", "header", or "message" elements.
